title: Kinetic Theory - single atom speed and temp

content.question: In a sample of a monatomic ideal gas, a particular gas atom has speed <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> at time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. At a later time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, the gas atom has speed <math alttext="v sub 2 equals 2 v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly indicates how the temperature of the gas may have changed, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: The temperature may have increased or decreased, because the speed of a single atom does not provide information about the average speed of all of the atoms in the sample.
The temperature may have increased or decreased, because temperature is not related to the average speed of gas atoms.
The temperature must have increased, because the speed of all atoms increases with increasing temperature.
The temperature must have increased, because the increase in speed of the atom will increase the overall average speed of all of the atoms in the sample.

content.answer: The temperature may have increased or decreased, because the speed of a single atom does not provide information about the average speed of all of the atoms in the sample.
